div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.

Paid up '' £ 5oo,ooo
Reserve Fund... 5oo,ooo
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

MONDAY, AUGUST 7, 1905.

div.head: THE VIST OF THE FRENCH FLEET.
div.p: The official program of the festivities in connection with the visit of the French fleet leaves nothing to be desired. His Majesty the King will review the French Fleet, Admiral Caillard and his gallant and distin guished staff will be his guests, and are specially invited to witness the races for the King’s Cup. Windsor Castle is to be thrown open to our friendly rivals, and we may be sure that our Ruler has still some pleasant surprises in store for his guests. The City of London follows the example of the King ; Portsmouth may be trusted to live up to its reputation, and last but not least, the two Houses will entertain the French officers in Westminster Hall. Six years agp who could have proposed that the centenary year of the Trafalgar would be marked by the fraternisation of the French and British Fleets at Portsmouth following on the friendly visit of a Spanish King to London Yet nothing could be more necessary in the the interests of the peaces of the world, than the “entente cordiale” between two nations whose ideals as to progress and liberty are identical, whose mutual commercial inter ests increase daily and whose ancient quarrels have become a source of mutual respect. Our soldiers and sailors have not always had the best of the give and take. If the British Fleets swept the seas under Nelson and Collingwood, they were well nigh swept from the seas during the later years of the American war, when Guioben and Suffren commanded victor ious squadrons of which any Admiral might have been proud, and though we triumphed under the leadership of the great Iron Duke and the greater Marlborough, the names of Froute noy, Lauffeld, Steinkirk, and neerwinden attest that even the soldiers who swore- and fought- so terribly in Flanders often met their match. Let us,rather, while remembering our victories, forget against whom they were gain ed and while profiting by out defeats cease to underline in our minds the name of the con queror. Thus Crecy and Bovines, Hastings and Waterloo, may became names of peaceful omen.

We remember a passage in an English novel - alas! the author;s name has escaped us- that bears on this point. Two Englishmen meet in the one guest-room of a tiny hotel in Ireland. Both eye one another over their pipes and one suddenly exclaimed, “Excuse me, but-er-didn’t we meet last behind the fives courts at X…” “Yes,” replies the other, laugh ing, “and call-over stopped it after the fifth round ;” and the two discuss their old school- days and school quarrels with the greatest good humor in the world. May such be the relations of France and England in the future. They have led a wild and rather quarrelsome youth, they have fought one another out of sheer pugnacity, or out of mutual jealously born of the other’s attentions to various colored enchantresses in Asia and Africa and the Spanish Main, but they are settling down now to a law-abiding and steady middle age. John is ready to admit that Jacques is a right good fellow in spite of his theatrical manner, and Jacques in convinced that John’s reserve hides a warm and friendly heart and both are inclined to think more fondly of Edward the Peacemaker and President Loubet that of William the Conqueror and the Edward who took Calais. Their old war-songs cease to call up memories of battle and Marot;s refrain. “Car France est cimitiere aux Anglsis” and Drayton’s ballad of Agincourt appeal to day to mixed audiences.

div.head: THE MARSHALL ISLANDS
div.p: Australian sensitiveness in connection with German aggressiveness in the Marshall Islands is not likely to be blunted by any tranquilising assurance from minor officials. To give strength and validity to such under takings,, it is essential that they should come direct from Prince von Bulow. Australians will want to know, therefore, whether the German Consul at Sydney had the Chan cellor;s authority for stating that the new laws for the government of the insular group will be framed “in accordance with Aus tralians wishes.” Until about 20 years ago, England and Germany had practically the same footing in the islands. But Downing street, fearing that this dual control might breed future complications, as between England and France in the New Hebrides, gravely affronted Australian sentiment by consenting to the establishment of a German Protectorate. It was strictly covenanted, however, that the than “open door,” should remain open. But Teutonio smartness hit on an expedient to close it. The administra tive control, including all fiscal arrange ments was handed over to a private com mercial concern, the Jaluit Company, which at once proceeded to build up a trading mono poly for its own exclusive profit. One method was the imposition of a duty of L3 per ton on exports in Australian vessels ; but to give this arbitrary act a show of fairness, the same burden was placed on German ship engaged in the business, and so whatsoever sum t disbursed for export duty came back to its treasury as revenue. Australians will wait to see whether Prince von Bulow is of the same mind as this Consular spokesman of his at Sydney.

div.head: THE PEACE COMMISSION. DELEGATES AT OYSTER BAY. MR. ROOSEVELTS TOAST
div.p: New York, August 5. M. Witte and Baron Rosen paid a visit to President Roosevelt at Oyster Bay, similar to that of Baron Kamoura and M. Takashira last week, with the object of informally eating their respects prior to to-day’s formal reception. It is stated that the question of precedence today has been decided in favor of Japan. (R.)

WASHINGTON, August 5. The plenipotentiaries have arrived at Oyster Bay. The envoys were received by President Roosevelt on board the Government yacht Mayflower. The Japanese preceded the Russians. (Reuter.)

OYSTER BAY, August 5. Mr. Witte handed a letter from the Tsar to Mr. Roosevelt yesterday. Mr. Roosevelt gave a lunch to the Russian and Japanese plenipotentiaries. In his toast he expressed an ardent wish for the conclusion of a just and lasting peace. (Haus.)

WASHINGTON, August 6. President Roosevelt presented the envoys to each other. A luncheon then followed, at which Mr. Roosevelt proposed a toast to the welfare and prosperity of the two great nations, saying that it was his earnest prayer in the interest of all mankind, that a just and last- ing peace may be speedily concluded.
The envoys shook hands cordially when introduced. Before leaving, the Japanese ex- pressed professional gratification at the pleasant meeting. (Reuter.)

div.head: CHECK ON RUSSIAN AUTOCRACY
MEETING OF GRAND COUNCIL
div.p: ST. PETERSBURG, August 5. Despite the opposition of the reactionary party, the Council of the Empire which met at Peterhof has decided that no bill rejected by a two-thirds majority shall be submitted for the Tsar’s sanction. If the bill be rejected by less that two-thirds majority, reports, both form the majority and minority, will be sub- fitted to the Tsar, who will decide between the two. This decision is important in solving the introduction of the first check on the autocratic power. (Reuter.)
ST. PETERSBURG, August 3. The Grand Council has decided to accept the project of M. Bouliguine, constitution an assembly of purely consultative representa- tives. (Heaus).

div.head: RUSSIAN STRIKES
COSSACKS FIRED ON
div.p: ST. PETERSBURG, August 5. It is officially announced that strikers at Novo Rossiak (Cancasia) fired upon a detach- ment of Cossacks, killing one. The Cossacks returned the fire killing 30 and wounding 22. (Reuter.)
ST. PETERSBURG, August 6. The reservists have been called up for service on the Transcaucasian railways, the employs of which have gone on strike. (H.)

div.head: ADVANCE JAPAN:
div.p: TOKIO, August 6. The Japanese have introduced a civil admi- mistration at Dalny and Port Arthur. Five thousand Japanese colonists have already arrived at Yingkow. (Reuter.)

div.head: SENTENCED TO DEATH:
div.p: Moscow, August 5. The assassin of Count Shouvaloff has been condemned to death. (Heaus.)

div.head: THE MOROCCO QUESTION
ANOTHER STUMBLING BLOCK
div.p: TANGIER, August 5. The French proposals to Germany are regard- ed as exceedingly modest, but though the approval of Germany is considered likely, the objections of the Moorish Court may prove insurmountable. (Reuter.)

div.head: THE “ENTENTE CORDIALE.”
FRENCH FLEET AT COWES.
div.p: CHERBOURG, August 6. The French fleet has sailed for Cowes, where the King and Queen arrived yesterday evening on the Royal yacht. (Reuter.)
CHERBOURG, 6. The French squadron left for Cowes. (H.)

div.head: THE COTTON TRADE
WORKMEN’S DEMANDS REJECTED
div.p: LONDON, August 5. The Federation of Cotton Spinners has decided to urge the whole trade to unite in rejecting the workmen’s demand for 5% increase of wages, The Bolton employers have decided to enforce a reduction of 5%

div.head: ARMY BEER CONTRACT
div.p: We understand that Ind, Coope and Co., Limited, of Burton- on-Trent and Romford, have secured the renewal of their contract for the supply of the whole of the troops in Egypt for a further period.

div.head: DROWNING FATALITY
div.p: Th body of a native was picked up yesterday by some Araba who saw it floating in the Mahwoudieh Canal and handed it over to the police. It was taken to the hospital, where the inquest appears to have established the fact that death was caused entirely by drowning, there being no suspicion of foul play.

div.head: ALHAMBRA THEATER
div.p: Pressure on our space unfortunately compels us to hold over our repot of the excellent opening performance of the Della Guardia Italian dramatic company in Fedora on Saturday. We understand that subscription tickets for 30 performances may be had at P.T. 300. These may be obtained at the box office form the 10th to the 10th inst.

div.head: BRAWL IN A CAFE
div.p: The Café Imperial was the scene of a quarrel on Saturday evening which resulted in a tradesman of Jewish origin, who is, we believe, a British subject, receiving three serious stabs between the shoulders with a stiletto, which were inflicted by the nephew of the injured man. Dispute over a game of cards seems to have led to the assault.

div.head: THE PLAUGE
div.p: Staurday’s plague bulletin reports the death of a native street-cleaner of Satret el Bahir district of Alexandria, who was found dead at his house. Sunday’s bulletin reports two admissions to hospital and three deaths at Alexandria, and also one death at Port Said. The new cases at Alexandria are those of an Italian grocer of the Chimerly district, and a native street-cleaner of the Echeches Ragheb Pasha. The three cases which ended fatally were all natives, one being the nephew of the second case admitted to hospital yesterday, who was found dead at his home, another was a native workman who had been working in the same shop as the case reported in Saturday, and the third was a native workman found dead at his home in Saladin.

div.head: MESSIEURS. WALKER AND MEIMARACHI, LTD.
div.p: formally inaugurated their reconstructed bar in Old Bourse Palace- which has risen, Phoenix-like, from its ashes- on Saturday even- ing by inviting the members of the local press to a “champagne de press.” The guests had thus an pooprtunity of inspecting the rea;;y magnificent appointments of the bar at their leisure while enjoying a glass of Montebello. The up-to-date manner, and nothing has been overlooked that could ass to the comfort and convenience of clients. The artistic decora- tions, which are usually gorgeous and reflect the greatest credit on the designer, Prof. Kirchmayr, make the establishment one of the most inviting of the kind we have yet seen, The scheme of decoration of the front part of the bar is carried out is “art nounvean,” while the back parlor is a gem of arabesque work, being entirely furnished with masharabieh and bass furniture from Messers. Tara’s workshops. Here, besides enjoying the refreshments supplied, one may read the latest newspapers and magazines in the great- best ease and comfort. Altogether, the place is really worth a visit, and Messers. W. and M. are to be congratulated on affording Alexandria such a pleasant place of meeting, A feature of the establishment is the commissionaries who is an imposing figure of something like 7 feet.

div.head: THE SUN’S ECLIPES.
div.p: MISSIONS LEAVE FOR ASSOUAN.

The maulers of the British and American astronomical missions which have been sent out in order to observe the forthcoming eclipse of the sun have arrived in Cairo and leave for Assouan this evening, accompanied by Captian Lyons. Captain Lyons will return to Cario on August 31, bu the date of return of the mis- sions is not yet fixed. Another expedition consisting of Russian savants, is due to arrive in Egypt shortly.
On August 30 the moon passes exactly between the sun and our earth, and produces the comparatively rare phenomenon of a total eclipse of the sun.

It is only on such occasions that the corona or halo of light which surrounds the sun, can be seen at all, and it is in consequence of this fact that astronomers journey to distant parts of the earth from which the eclipsed sun can be observed.

For European observers the line of totality of the approaching eclipse is very conveniently placed, so that it can be reached quiet easily and at a small expense. The elliptical shadow of the moon on the earth’s surface moves from Hudson’s Bay to Arabia, so that the path traced out is considerable length, but only about 120 miles broad.

To observe the corona, therefore it is neces- say to place oneself somewhere on this small strip of the the earth’s surface. After leaving the American continent at Labrador, the shadow sweeps across the Atlantic and strikes Europe near Cape Ortega, in the north-west of Spain, passes over Spanish territory, convenient towns traversed being Oviedo, Valencia, Bur- dos, Ateca, Calatayud, and Castellón. The shadow then crosses the Mediterranean, pass- ing over the islands of Majoroa and Ivisa and cuts the African continent near Philippeville and Callo, in Algeria. in its eastward course it falls on Sfax in Tunia, and numerous coast stated in Tripoli, and towards the end of its career passes over Egypt near Assouan, and finally terminates in Arabia.

The facts that the eclipse occurs in the month of Augustm when many people can afford the time to visit Southern Europe, that the track is comparatively near home, that totality last for over three minutes, and fi- nally that this is the only total solar eclipse that can be easily reaches from England for some years to come, account for the great popular interest attached to this event.

Astronomers have been making very exten- sive preparations for securing as many photo- graphs and observations as possible, and, according to present arrangements they are about to take up their stations along this narrow line.
The names of the astronomers who are leaving for Assouan this evening are Mr. Keeling, mr. Joy, Dr. West, Mr. Ballamy Professor H. Turner, and Dr. and Mrs. Hausey.

div.head: EGYPTIAN ARMY.
div.p: Leave of absence has been granted to the following officials of the Sudan Government and Army officers until the undermentioned dates:-

El Kaimakam Herbert Bey, Assistant Adju- cant General, Recruiting, until November 1; El Kaimakam Pearson Bey. Director of Sur- vets, until September 18; EL Bimbashi Das -sey-Browning, Medical Corps, until October 15; El Bimbasbi Potter, 16th Battalion, until October 19; EL Kaimaskam Wood Bey, officer commanding 2nd Battalion and EL Bimbasbi Ryan. div.head: NILE GAUGE READINGS.
div.p: The non-arrival of the gauge readings from Rosaries since the 20th of the last month is due to the fact that the telegraph office has been closed on account of the illness of th clerk. On Saturday last the office was still closed but the irrigation inspector telegraphed the missing reading of the last month from Slings, a station some thirty miles from Rosaries and we are now able to complete our July table.

We can easily understand the inconvenience which would be caused by the illness of a telegraph clerk in such a remote district and the difficulty of replacing him at a moment’s notice, but the Telegraph Administration must have now been aware of the fact for about a fortnight. It is a very serious matter to deprive the public of telegraphic communica- tion to any station for even the shortest period but when a telegraph office is closed for more than a fortnight, merely on account of a clerk’s illness, it would seem that the authorities show a considerable disregard for the public which takes some interest in the Nile flood.

div.head: AN IMPORTANT DISCOVERY.
HIDDEN TREASURE AT TOUKH EL GARAMOUS.
div.p: A Tell or mound, close to the village of Touch el Garamous, in the Facous district, has yielded a magnificent treasure to the Antiquities Service. It appears that a few months agate Government authorised a rich proprietor of the neighbourhood to take sebakh from the mound and with that object gangs if villagers not to work to dig outtings into the Tell, which rises some 10 metres above the surrounding lines, and a Deauville railways was constructed to remove the loads of sebakh as fast as they were dug out.

The Government had prudently inserted a clause in the contract insisting on all the necessary precautions being taken to protect an antiquities that might be discovered during the digging, and the Antiquities Ser- vice posted a ghaffir on the spot who was charge to protect its interests. In August 3 the ghaffir was riding over the Tell on a donkey, when the beast suddenly came down heavily. The rider after picking himself up, found that one of the ass’s forelegs had gone through the roof of a vault. He enlarged the opening and saw a treasure; two or three watchers rushed to the spot, the village follow- ed in a body, and the nearest omdeh was sent for.

Lord Cromer, in his report for 1904 re- marks that causes have come before him in which omdehs have shown the most praise- worthy tact and presence of mind. The omdeh of Toukh el Garamous Ahmad Effendi And ed Ali, appears to have possessed the ;after virtue in a high degree. Finding the gaffer executing the villagers of desiring to steal the objects in the vault and the villagers accusing the gaffer of having already stolen most of them the omdeh kept the crowd away called up the sheikhs and ordered them to guard the vault for the night wired to the Antiquities Service and the Momour of th earkas and though we cannot guarantee the last item, put the ghaffir under observation. He then took an inventory of the objects discovered.

On the evening of the 3rd inst. the native Inspector of the Antiquities Service came up from Faoour. The Inspector from Zagazig followed next day, and the treasure about which the energetic omdah and the sheik had camped all nights put under guard Saab, according to out informants, are the de- tails of this most interesting discovery. If the list of the objects discovered, which we have received is substantially accurate it is obvious that a find of the highest impor- dance and value has been made.

Here are some of the principle objects which have been inventoried- 2 silver bowls. one of them gilt, 2 candlesticks, a silver crown a silver figure of a cock, part of the head of a silver statuette covered with gold lead, a pair of gold polished bracelets with the clapse carved in the shape of a bird with a housing face, a bracelet with the figure of Horus on the catch a gold bracelet shaped like a serpents with a red stone set in the head, a golden diadem set with jewels, nine plates of silver a chased silver bowl, 17 silver and 118 gold coins, th leather bearing either the head of monarch, or the figures of a bird, etc. etc.

We imagine from the appearance of the coins is this list that the treasure will prove to be Roman or Psolemaic. Owing to the absence of all its European inspectors the Antiquities Service at Cario has been unable to furnish us with any information on the subject.

div.head: ENGLISH MISSION TO JERUSALEM
div.p: Arrangements are now almost completed for the pilgrimage of members of the English Church Union to the Holy lean, and the departure has been fixed for Nov. 3. The Anglican Bishop in Jerusalem, Dr .Blyth will travel with the party, and it is proposed to hold services, at Nazareth on Nov. 14. On Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Nov. 20, 21, and 22 there will be special celebrations of the Eucharist in the Chapel of Abraham in the Church of the Holy Sepultures the Patriarch of Jerusalem having given the requisite per- mission

They will be transferred to the ground Sour as soon as the necessary changes in the building with are in course of completion have been carried through.

The comptoir National’s capital amounts to fry 150000000 all paid yo. div.p: The Menageries S.S Niger, form Marseilles passed the Staites of Mernia on Saturday at 2 p.m. an is due here tomorrow morning.

div.head: NOTES FROM PORT SAID.
A REMARKABLE TOW. (FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT )
div.p: Port Said, Sunday. We had here yesterday a large tug, the Oceans on her return voyage from Saborg in Sumatra. This vessel on the 9th May was sighted coming in from the sea, having in tow a large vessel evidently much larger than herself. The Oceans of 115 tons net, and her consort the Tankerville whose tonnage was 2320 had come out form Eastern Europe in 17 days, and although the monsoon is blowing all the time in the Arabian sea, they proceeded and eventually arrived in safety. This tow, both for its length (over 8000 miles) and its freedom form serious accident is well worthy of note. I was informed that all went well on the voyage the tug coaling form her tow as occasions demanded and that but little occurred to mar the success of what is one of the greatest tows with have been made for some years. THE Tankerskille is an oil vessel intended for the carriage of petroleum on the Sumatra coast.
THE MATIANA

The Matiana (which vessel went badly ashore on Friday and completely blocked all traffic for some time) is now anchor in Lake Tim- san (Ismailia ) undergoing repairs to her steering gear, a defect in which was the cause of the accident, She will probably leave on Monday.
HARBOR IMPROVEMENTS

A tremendous amount of work in being done on downs Poiut in anticipation of the con- striation of stored and warehouses. Roads are being altered stretches of land leveled and quantities of sand are being removed to the Lake ashore near the spot where in the near future will be built the MAtarieh canal terminus

The “Chantier des Bloca” has also been much altered half being cut away and walls having been built to protect the banks of what is intended to bed in the future the danger anborges The eastern side of the aneborge approach will be protected by a stone breakwater a large portion of which is already completed. The bathing house are I believe to be pulled down at the end of the summer and the site noe occupied by them is to be dredged to a depth of 8 metres This will permit of dredgers hoppers and craft of a like nature all going into their berths and maneuvering quite clear of all the sea-going traffic instead of as at permit using the main channels and frequently greatly disturb- ing the harbour traffic.

div.head: NOTES FROM SUEZ
RUSSIAN HOSPITAL SHIP (FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT)
div.p: The Russian hospital ship Kostroma belong- ing to the 3rd division of Admiral Rodjetveien keys squadron is expected to arrive ar Suez shortly from Shanghai with wounded on board It will be remembered that this ship was cap- turred by the Japanese during the great navel battle and taken to Sasebom owing it was alleged to her having infringed he Hagues Conventions The Kostroms was subsequently released.
THE MATIANA

The B.I. steamer Matiana which grounded in the Canal yesterday forenoon came off without assistance in the afternoon at 4 o clock and proceeded to Imaillis where she will remain a day or two owing to a breakdown in her sheering gear.
SMALL DANCE

Last Friday evening a number of the members of the Cercie International at Port Tewik arranged a dance in honor of the captain and officers of the ETC cable ship Elector which is leaving Suez next Tuesday morning on her way home. She will be relieved by the Duplex due at Port Said on or about Wednesday Dancing was kept up to alate hour and was attended by a large number of the European residents of Suez and Port Tweak

div.head: CRICKET
div.p: London, August 5 Kent beat Surret by ten wickets. Jetta Gloucestershire and Yorkshire Hampshire were abandoned. The rest of the matches for this date were drawn.

A.C.C ROYAL BERKSHIRE REGIMENT Played on Saturday last. The regiment won the toss and sent in Capt. Moore and Mr. Strange who made a fair start putting on 23, when the former fell to a fast ball from Maclarei. A collapse followed six wickets going down for 39, and though Capt. Binglay and Pta. Webb added a few by hitting out, that total for the innings was only 13. H.B. Carver was the most successful of the Club bowlers. With an easy task before them, the A.C.C. bataman treated the Regiment’s bowling with a great want of respect, and after Maclaren had left at 16, H.B. Carver and Stacey did what they pleased till the score reached 175, when Carver, in getting back to hook a lob, trod on his wicket. His innings of 101 was marked by great vigour and brilliancy and he gave no chances till he had made 78, when he might have been caught twice and stumped once. Macaulay who came in next, hit extremely freely all round the wicket and was not out when stumps were drawn, with a vigorous 77 to his credit. Stacey, who played with more freedom than usual, carried out his bat for a chanceless 87 the club thus winning easily and decisively. Score-

div.head: THE HEDJAZ RAILWAY
div.p: The following letter from Alexandria appears in the latest issue to hand of the “Spectator”- When it was announced that the Ottoman Government had decided to construct a railway from Damascus to the Holy Cities of Islam, British journals, influenced no doubt by pessi- mystic experts, took little to no interest in the scheme. A few German military periodi- cals noted the strategical importance of the railway, and one or two paragraphs appeared in French papers protesting against the injury done to the French Damascus- Mercrib line through the construction of a rival railway by the government which had granted the Campagine des Chemins de fer de la Syria a monopoly of construction in the Hauran. In the Muslem world the news was received with joy by all the supporters of the Pan- Islamic propaganda so sedulously encouraged by Yildizm and subjects of the Sultan vied with one another in their praises of the saga- petty of their Sovereign and subscribed large sums to the funds of the Hamidie Hejaz line. Other Moslems, who looked on the Sultan and his Turks as barbarous naur- pers and longed for an Arab Khalifate, showed less enthusiasm their religious sen- timents were vanquished or at least neu- tralised by their political opinions. A railway might carry multitudes of Hajia to Mecca it would certainly transport thousands of Os- manli soldiers to the Hedjaz and there was no reason why the railway once carried to Mecca should not be prolonged to the Yemen, It has been suggested to me that it was the dread of this result, co-operating with Turkish misgovernment that has made the rising of 1905 in the Yemen and Asir provinces so des- perate and so gusoral.

During a brief holiday which I spent in Syria this year I travelled from Damascus to Ma’su the present terminus of the Hedjaz line. I have nothing but praise for the construction of the railways. The German and Italian engineers employed by the Turkish Government are as capable as the are honest and some sections of the line notably in the hills above Amman and on the unfinished branch linking Haifa and Derse, compare very favorably with the line over the Lebanon and some of the Swiss mountain railways. The material is fair but there personnel cannot be described as efficient. The Germans and Italian cannot train the whole staff and a great proportions of the employes are Turkish or Arab soldiers whose ignorance of there work is complete. To clap a stationmaster;s uniform on an ex-non-commis- ioned officer of calvary does not make him an efficient stationmaster; yet that is the policy that the military authorities have followed in the selection of most of their Moslem subordi- notes. the line is at present open for traffic to a paint 475 kilometers south of Damascus and about four days march form the Turkish port of Akabs on the Red Sea. The soldier workmen have completed the embankments and prepared the track for the thirty miles further south, and the survey parties have pushed sixty miles more into the interior of Midian. The German and Italian experts will be polite;y dismissed as soon as the rails near the Holy Cities and Moslem understudies are now being trained who will it is hoped, replace them successfully. I doubt whether the construction of the sec- tons confined to these officials will prove as cheap.

I have emphasized the military character of the line, and I must emphasise it again. Although the Damascus-Amman and the Half-Deras sections run through some extreme- ly fertile districts, the line as a whole can never pay. South of Amman a rocky wilderness succeeds a barren steppe and there are a few more desolate countries in the world than Arabia Patras and the interior of Midan. food, forage, and in some places water have to be railed down for th supply of the troops on the line between El Hasa and Ma’an, an d the country for a hundred an fifty miles to the south is equally unproductive. The pilgrim traffic is never likely to do more than balance the damage done to the carriages by thievish or careless Hajia and the wear and tear of the Haj. But in the last week of February and the first fortnight or so of March over twenty thousand soldiers, two-thirds of them Syrian Moslem reservists were untrained at Damascus and Amman an march ed across the desert to Akaba. There were admitted defects in the mobilization an accidents on the railway were only averted say the Turks by the special interposition of the Prophet. The men suffered from hunger form the bitter night cold of the

high desert plateau across which the has been laid many deserted on the way and sought refuge among the Hauran Druses and the Bedouin and the losses averaged about eight per cent in the twenty-four battalions that used the line. Still, the performance did some credit to the Staff of the Fifth Army Corps. and will no doubt be improved upon should another mobilisation of Syrian Moslems be risked when the Haifa Dersa section is open to traffic, and the railway material for the purpose of renewing or prolonging the line can be sent op cheaply and rapidly from the coast.

Yet a few years and the linking up of the Anatolian lines with the Aleppo-Demascus and Damascus-Hedjaz systems will enable the Otto= man Government to send its best troops from Europe and Anatolia to Demascus, Ma’au or Mecca by rail without the slightest risk of interference form the sea. Today the outlying provinces of the Turkish Empire are at the mercy of any nation that possess a fleet and can transport thirty thousand men to Syria or Arabia, In ten years’ time railway power will enable the Ottoman dynasty to meet the me- nance of sea power with more confidence than in the past.

The Sultan of course gets the credit of the Hedjaz Railway scheme with he Moslem world, but I am informed by persons who have had success to sources of information which are closed to the world in general that the real originator or the scheme was General vou der Goltz, whose plans for the defense of the Ottoman Empire included the construction of great strategical lines which would enable the Turk - wish Empire as a potential ally whose interven- ion is the Caucasians might contain large forces loch would otherwise be hurried the Austrian and German frontiers. But the over- throw of the Mosoovite on land and sea has made Russo-Turkish or Russo German war highly improbable and it is possible that the German-trained strength of the Turkish Empire may be employed against another foe when the great railways are ready.

There can be no doubt that Germany has to a great extent supplanted us in Turkey. Our snarls and grimaces unaccompanied by mili- tary action during the American massacres were constructed by the Turks with that friendly support and diplomatic cordiality evinced by the German Emperor during those years of horror. Our veiled protectorate over Koweit out presence in wgypt out sympathy with the Macedonian and Armenians do not endear us to the Sultan and since the conclusion of the Anglo-French Agreements the sole opposition we have to face in Egypt is subventioned and supported by the Pan-Islamic leaders at Stamboul.

German hostility to Great Britain is no new thing, though we have recognised it rather late in the day. With Turkey hostile to the first Moslem Power in the world, German ambitions might contemplate the possibility of using the Turkish forces to create a formidable diversion during an Anglo-German conflict at Koweit and on the Egyptain border. I am aware that the devotees of sea power proclaim that Egypt is and must remain the prize of the Power tat controls the seas. But the Suez Canal could be blocked with the greatest ease, Ma’An is only fifteen marobes form Ismailia and though the Sinai Peninsula and the desert of El Tih are inhospitable enough, large armies have entered Egypt from the north-east since the dawn of history, and th eTurkish solder re- quires little but bread,water, and cartridges. The concentration of an army is Southern Palestine would not be hard to screen, and even of the first attack proved a total failure, it might well be repeated with greater success. And can we assume that the first attack would val even if the Sudan remained absolutely quite and certain elements in Egypt required do watching 1. The movement on Egypt would be by two or three corps d’ arovee collected in Syria for the catencible purposes of suppressing an Arab or Druse rising; and whatever may be said oft he natural difficulties, Sultan Selim and the Saracen rulers of Egypt and Syria took large and well-equipped armies across the same desert in the past. The difficulty if inducing the Ottoman Government to take the risk would no doubt be considerable, but German influence has made such strides in Turkey that the conclusion of an offensive and defensive alliance between the Kaiser and Sultan Ab- dul-hamid is now a possibility.

If ever the rivalry between England and German y comes to a head, it is not unlikely that our great opponents will do her utmost to force us to a land struggle and use Moslem fanaticism as one of her weapons. The Kaiser’s intervention on Morocco has had its effect in the Near East. It has confirmed the impression made by the Imperial visit and the sedulous attentions paid to the Sultan ever since 1890 just as the stories of “British intrigue in Arabia” “British designs on Mecca” . to which the German Press had given a wide circulation have influenced the Pan-Islamic party, which now begins to look on England as an implacable enemy.

div.head: JAPAN AND AUSTRALIA
A NOTE OF ALARAM
div.p: The progress of the conflict between Japan and Russia has had a greater interest for Aus- tralians then for any other non-Asiatic com- munity, by reason of the proximity of their country to the scene of operations. When Russian obtained possession of Vladivostock grave apprehension s were entertained last in the event of a rupture with Great Britain , it should be made a bare of hostile operation s against the island-continent and those fears were renewed after the seisure of Port Arthur in the termination of war between China and Japan. With its extensive coast lire of about 8,850 miles and numerous spacious but unprotected harbors, the Commonwealth is practically at the mercy of a hostile fleet, despite the presence of the Australian Squad- ran and it si al but certain that in the event of a rupture with Great Britain , a landing followed by area occupation, would be effect- ed on the northern coast, while the British was vessels were engaged in defending southern ports. This state of affairs has never serious- ly engaged the attention of either the Aus- tralian Parliaments or people, every movement in the direction of improving the Federal de- fences being regarded as san excuse for increas- ing the public expedenture.

Of late, however considerable misgivings have been awakened with regard to the future policy of a victorious Japan towards the Commonwealth. It is admitted that the Australian treatment of Japanese as alien, the Japanese crews of Japanese vessels in Commonwealth ports not being allowed on shore, has created feelings of irritation through- out the land of the Mikado, which, although at present kept under restraint, may occasion trouble after peace has been proclaimed. But this policy of indiscriminate restricted im- migration was entirely the work of the Australian Labour party, which has declared war against the presence of coloured aliens, whether British subjects or otherwise, on Commonwealth shores, even where their labour is essential to the development of local indus- tries, as in Queensland. It is not understood in Japan that the Australian people, as a whole, had no hand or part in the restrictions imposed upon Japanese desirous of visiting Australia. Hence it is simply natural that one complementary expressions respecting the Commonwealth and its residents should be frequently heard among the Japanese people. It would be strange were it otherwise But the Japanese authorities are better informed, and do not appear disposed to move in the matter beyond asking that the law be modified so as to allow the same facilities to Japanese visiting the Commonwealth as are allowed Australian landing at Japanese ports.

Meanwhile, a note of alarm is being vigorously sounded by a portion of the Australian Press respecting the future policy of the Japanese Government towards the Commonwealth. It is asserted that the pos- session of Northern Australia, with its many millions of acres of unexplored country and mere handful of white population, is coveted by the Japanese who behold in ti the future source of untold wealth. “It is not a country for the white man” a Japanese magnate is reported to have asserted, “yet rather than allow it to be developed by those most capable of so doing, you prefer it to remain a complete wilderness.” There is much truth on this definition of the dog-in-the-manger policy of the Federal Government, but it is very unlikely that the Japanese authorities have given a thought tot he future of northern Australia. For many years to come Formoss, Korea and countries affording a wider scope for Japanese enterprise that the land of the Southern Cross. But the prophets of evil are not to be cornered. There insist that when the Russians have been driven back into Sibera, the “Yellow Peril” will become a tangible fact. Perhaps the wish is father to the thought.

The Japanese in Australia bitterly resent these imputation in the good faith of their fellow countrymen towards what they regard as one of the richest portions of the British Empire, and point out that a rupture with their great ally would be simply playing into the hand of Russia and Germany. Much, however, depends on the action of the Labour Party, both in the Commonwealth and in the States. In their determination to secure “a white Australia” a laudable ambition in some reports the leaders are utterly indifferent to the possibility of complication with other peoples. This is the real danger of the future. “The real policy of Japan,” said a recent visitor, “will be not to speak possession of any port of Australia or Polynesia, but to build up its country and possession of the territories wrested from the grip of the Russian, we shall have more than sufficient to occupy our industrial energies for the next hundred years.” There was considerable truth in these observations. Australians most conversant declare that its trend is in favor of the development of Japan;s commercial and in- dustrial resources rather than the pursuit of a Napoleonic ideal.

div.head: MME. ADAM’S REMINISCENCES
div.p: That famous lady Madame Adam, or Ju- liege, Lambert, who once possessed so much influence, social, and political, in the Thurd Republic, has followed up the publication of her memoirs. by a new volume of much in- terse untitled “Mes sentiments et nos Idées avant 1870.” It is issued by Lemerre, and Madame Adam dates her new series of remini- scenes from the year 1865, when she was in the South of France, on the horse in the Golfe Juan, near Cannes, with her father, Docot Lambert , her mother and the daughter. There Madame Adam was visited by many notabil- ities, including Prosper Merimee and Dr. Mare, a great friend o fM.Thiers. Politics were much discussed at these visits, and it is interesting to note that at this period Thieres as Maure showed, foresaw the daughter looming from the side of Germany, whereas Merimee a staunch Imperialist, refused to believe in any possible diminution of French prestige. An- other strong imperialist, Ales-Dufour, was also a visitor at Madame Adam’s villa, and be too, trusted firmly in that star of Napoleon III. This Aries-Dufour belonged to the Man- chester school, and corresponded with Cobden. He believed in the Universal Exhibition, the fraternity of the nations, and peace societies. In fact, there was as much talk about peace and union in those days as in our own, and Dufour went so far as to call Napoleon III. “Mon Emperor Pacifist” in the face of Madame Adam and her family. “A psoi- fits!” “After the next Universal Exhibi- tion,” replied Dufour, “there will be no more wars. That the conviction of Napoleon III., and it is mine.”

At this time, as Madame Adam writes, the exiles Louis Blane, Ledru-Rollin, Eugene Pel- letan, and Edmond Adam were calling upon the Republicans at home to act against the Empire, This was the subject of a remarkable conversation between Prosper Merimes and Madame Adam, Merimes was prophetic in ut- trance, “Do you believe, Juliette Lambert, you who are a sincere Liberal, “ he said, “that the Peyrata, the Challemel-Lacours, the Aragos, and the Jacobin descendants, the Brissons, the Ferrys, and the Rancs would give you liberty if they had the Government in their hands. They are the sons of Robespierre, of Saint-Juste of Marat. If ever they get the power they will go to work not only like the Terrorist, but like the Church in its darkest days. They are a church in themselves, these fanatics of anti-clericalism a church smaller than the other, just just as dogmatic. They regard themselves as free intellects, but they are only irritating the others by not accepting their formulas. Between that Church if these and the Church of the clericals I make no distinction. I am free, too, in intel- let. I am a Liberal a sincere anti-clerical but there others- “and here the con- version was interrupted by the arrival of Victor Cousin, who, hearing Merimes’s last words, said, “Oh, I see the black spectre is still with you.” “Oh , no,” said Merimes; “I was talking of the red spectre.” Cousin here complimented Madame Adam on her dress and her good looks. She returned the compliment in another way, whereupon Meri- mer called her a flatterer and said that she might have given the philosopher a few hints as to his own appearance and attire. “And,” say Madame Adam, “Cousin was really slovenly and did little honor to French letters while crowds of spruce Englishmen, brushed and rebrushed were pairing up and down in the croisette.” Thus Madame Adam continues in her chatty way, throwing side lights on many events leading up to the fall of the Second Empire.

What is far more interesting are her frag- memtary conversations with with all the most cele- rated people of her time. She has some m valuable pages on George Sand, and gives private views or glimpese of natal men in their shirt-sleeves, as it were. She knew every- body in her time, and was the friend of politicians of opposing factions, of Conserva- tives and Radicals, as well as of the literary and artistic people. Towards the close of the book is an entertaining chapter relating how Madame Adam was boycotted by the ladies at Cannes because she proclaimed herself to be a pagan, and said that she prayed to the divinities of Greece especially in climes of light and sunshine where Nature was most divine. The volume comes down to September, 1870 , when Madame Adma, her husband, and their great Italian friend, Signor Cernnus- ehi who became a neutralised Fenchman because France was vanquished by Germany were weeping together over the defeat of MacMahoun and the capitulation of Sedan.

div.head: BLESSINGS AND BEATINGS.
div.p: The proposition to gove the Russina peasants more land makes it interesting to note that so far, from the time of the great eneacipation, 159,606 members of the Noblemen’s Union have said to petty culturists 24,200,00 scres for L62,000,000. This idea of alternately blud- gooming and benefiting the peasants brings to memory a story of Archbishop Benson’s. A friend of his saw brought into a Russian police- court a priest in undress of purple. The magistrates and the police knelt and kissed this hand; then rising the magistrate said, “You nasty drunken beats, so you were drunk again yesterday. I’ll make you remember it this time.” And they led the priest out into the courtyard tore off his clothes, and gave him fifty lashes. When he was brought back , half- fainting, into the court, they all knelt again, kissed his hand, and received his blessing .

div.head: LARGE SLICE FOR RHODESIA
BAROTSE AWARD ADDS VALLEY OF THE UPPER ZAMBESI.
div.p: The award of the King of Italy respecting the western boundary of the Baroste kingdom, in North west Rhodesia, to settle the question which arose in 1903 between Great Britain and Portugal relative to the frontier of their respective spheres of influence in Central Africa, has been issued.

By the Treaty of 1891 the two States had agreed that he western line of division sepa- rating Rhodesia from thr Portuguese sphere of influence in Central Africa shall follow the centre of the channel of the Upper Zembasi starting from the Katie Rapids, at the south- eastern corner of the Portuguese territory of the Barotse kingdom, but the countries were unable to determine the western limits and accordingly King Victor Emmanuel was re- quested to give his decision upon the matter.

By considering as to which tribes in the kingdom recognised the King Lewanika as para- mount ruler on the day that the that y in question was signed the King of Italy marks the western frontier of the territory as the straight line running south of west between the Katina rapids on the Zambezi and the village of Andara on the Okavango, as far as the point where it meets the river Kwando for there the eastern side of the bed of the Kwando’s upper waters as far as the point of inter- section with the 24th meridian and northwards along this as far as the frontier of the Congo State.
By this award, England obtains between one-third and one-half of the debatable terri- tory and about 64, 000 square miles of terri- tory are added to the existing area of Rhodesia.

n'hésitent pas à se purger, quand elles en ont besoin. Elles ne craignent ni le dégoût ni la fatigue, parce que, à l'opposé des autres purgatifs, celui-ci n'opère bien que lorsqu'il est pris avec de bons aliments et des boissons fortifiantes, telles que vin, café, thé. Chacun choisit, pour se purger, l'heure et le repas qui lui conviennent le mieux, selon ses occupations. La fatigue de la purgation étant annulée par l'effet de la bonne alimentation, on se décide aisément à recommencer autant de fois que cela est nécessaire.

Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.
